segments.text: Were you stationed and what squadron were you flying with?
I was stationed in Yuban, Thailand.
I was with the 497 squadron in the 8th wing.
We were the night, we had the night mission ordinarily.
I was not on a night mission when I got shot down.
Okay, what type of mission were you flying?
I was flying mid-cap.
Okay.
And we had diverted
from the strike force to meet some MiGs coming up from the south, from Hanoi.
And we were up there just north of Hanoi.
In fact, I had started letting down chasing MiGs when I got shot down.
How were you shot down?
Was it a SAM?
No, I think it was ground fire.
I just felt the hit.
It felt like just a single hit.
in the engine section of the airplane.

But it was, it really, you know, started, all the lights coming on, and I just started climbing out back toward, back toward Laos when the controls burned through and I just, you know, the airplane kind of went ballistic.
Were you injured or wounded?
When you were shot down?
Or during your parachute down?
No, not really.
I had a little superficial shot on my leg and on my chin, and that's all.
Were you captured immediately after you parachuted out, or were you on the ground a couple days, hours?
No, I was...
I would think it was probably... not more than about an hour, but it seemed longer than that.
I was able to, I landed on top of a big hill, and the people from down below had seen the chutes, both my chute and my back chute, because the airplane had crashed before we got down.
It was spinning.
It spun in and hit the ground, so that alerted them to look up and see the chutes.
And it was on a Sunday afternoon, kind of like today.
a real bright, sunshiny day.
So, yeah, they saw the chutes, and they came charging up the hill after us.
But I had landed in a tree.
My chute hung up in a tree, and I was just overhanging a big bluff.
But only momentarily, I jerked on a vine that was nearby, and the chute released.
I landed on a big limb of a tree, and I unbuckled myself from the...
from the shoot and crawled down the tree and got out of there and found a place to get myself hidden.
And hopefully to make it till dark so that I could head west.
And I got my compass out and broke a limb so that I'd know which direction to start off in and all that stuff.
But they were
coming up all around me, looking for me.
I heard, you know, there were dogs and lots of people.
So was it the Viet Cong or villagers?
Just, I think, villagers and militia.
Yeah, there was some militia.
Some of the North Vietnam people, not in Viet Cong, of course, were in the South.
This was up near Hanoi.
Okay.
And...
They walked right by me, right very close to me, you know, several times over a period of an hour, two hours, sometimes, I don't know about that, time frame.
Before I saw a bare pair of feet.
It was just the one person who came up and I saw the feet stop and they started backing up.
And then they turned and ran.
So I knew that that person had spotted me.
All I could see was the feet, though.
And sure enough, of course, it came back shortly with some treatment.
After you were captured, where were you first taken?
Well, there was a big crowd.
that gathered around me when they captured me.
And there were two people, and they were civilians up there, but they could speak a little bit of English.
Two men who kind of took charge, and they, in fact, this one guy fired off a pistol right close to my head from behind me, and it really scared me.
I thought I was shot, but
He was just warning the crowd and making them get back, because they had swarmed all over.
We're trying to get all my clothes off.
I mean, that's what.
But he wanted to get me moving and out of the crowd so that he could claim credit for the capture and get whatever bounty that was offered.
I think that was the reason.
And so we took off.
And we ran for several hours.

during that afternoon until up until late well past dark and he secreted me into a place where they just held me there until they could turn me over to the army that evening later that evening they did just that and um along the way though there were there were people who

were trying to get me away from these two people that had me sort of like they were jerking and you know and we were just running and they were kind of fending off the drought but at any rate they turned me over to the army that night and they were really
We're rough, you know.
My backseater showed up and they had him at another place.
I hadn't seen him since we bailed out of the airplane.
They put us both in the back of a little old Jeep type vehicle.
And they took our boots off.
We never saw those again.
And they took a shoestring, one of the strings out of our boots and tied our big toes together along with...
They had us all tied up anyhow, but...
That was a particularly excruciating thing because they tied them real, real tight.
Kind of an odd thing to do, but that's what they did.
So did the Army take you to a real POW encampment?
They spent about three days just kind of fooling around and keeping us in one little place or another.
during the day and moving at night kind of secreting us into Hanoi.
We ferried across the river and so on.
We weren't very far from Hanoi from the beginning.
I figure maybe 30, 40 miles to the northwest.
But it took them about three days to get us to the Hanoi Hilton downtown Hanoi.
Did they have any English-speaking people there to question you or interrogate you once you got there?
Yeah.
What subjects did they try to cover during the interrogation?
Well, that's hard to explain.
They asked military questions.
But the interrogators, my impression then and later was that
You know, they were very crude.
And the questions they asked were things that were readily available to them.
I mean, the answers to that is in any kind of publication.
There's nothing else that would have been any kind of a military secret.
Just, you know, what squadron were you in and those kinds of things.
They had rosters in the squadron, so that wasn't a good thing.
But they did it.
And, of course, we and me, all of us, resisted to answering any questions, regardless of our innocuacy.
And so it was pretty tough because they were, as I said, it seemed to me that they were just in the business of...
practicing interrogation procedures and they were going to torture us, physically torture us, regardless of what the answers were.
The answers were kind of irrelevant.
But boy, they knew how to administer the torture, and they did that.
In my case, they kept me in the interrogation slash torture room under really bad conditions for about a week, I think.
I kind of lost track of time, because they really
I took most of it out.
And then they finally took me to a cell in the Hanoi Hilton, a little corner of the prison called the Mint.
There were three cells back there.
And I was the only one back there.
And the cell was about three feet wide by about six feet long.
It wasn't quite as long as I was.
And the bunk was 18 inches wide, and it was just hard wood, a wooden bench with ankle stocks in it, with a locker which was manipulated on the outside of the wall, which was about that big.
And they kept me locked in the stocks.
I stayed back there, I don't know, I think it was about 40 days.
See, I had to be certain.
Finally got moved up there to another part of the prison.
Still in solitary, though.
Uh-huh.
Sometime in February, I think.
And then I was still there in solitary for...
I told them about 90 days before they moved me.
They moved me to the zoo then.
Uh-huh.
How many POWs were in the camp at the time, or did you have any exposure to other POWs following your isolation?
Well, where I was,
I didn't know that I was in a camp where there were any more POWs.
I was back in the corner all by myself until I moved up into another little area of the prison.
It wasn't very far away from the man, but there were other POWs and other cells in that kind of hallway.
But they went to extremes.
measures to be sure that nobody saw anybody else or nobody communicated.
Although we managed to do a little of that and got caught at it and got tortured for it and so on.
I read a Reisner's book, The Passing of the Night, and he talks about, did y'all communicate with codes, tapping, and... Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
What y'all tried to find out when other prisoners came in and learned the names, the dog tag numbers?
Oh, yeah, we kept all the names.
Uh-huh.
It was just big volumes of communications every day.
Uh-huh.
Could you describe, like, a daily life in camp?
Is there such a thing as a routine day?
Well...
I don't know if I can remember.
Uh...
Routinely, you know, we got up early.
The gong went off, I guess, about daylight.
And we'd get up and just make up, then take the mosquito net down.
We had mosquito nets most of the time in the village.
And just wait around in there until, then usually they came by with water.
I don't know, it was like about nine o'clock.
And we'd fill up our little, everybody had an individual little jug for water.
You'd get one of them a day, a quart.
They might let you out to go,

In this place where we were, they had a bunch of wells, hand-dug wells, that you could take a bucket with a rope and bail out some old muddy water, and you could wash, dump a bucket of it over your head.
So sometimes the guard, if he got around to it, would go start doing that and give everybody.
He'd take one group out,

put them in this little fenced-in area around the well, let them have, you know, if there were three of us, in the case of when I was in the zoo for about 13 months, I lived with just two other guys, Red McDaniel and Al Runyon.
Then he'd give us maybe 20 minutes or so in there to get, and then put us back in the cell and get another group, you know.
But...
Theoretically, we weren't supposed to know that there was anybody else around anywhere.
And then they'd bring a meal that was, you know, it'd just be a big bucket that was carried on shoulder poles, or two of them, of soup and some rice.
The soup was just boiled weeds, like some of that stuff there or something, but...
We call it sewer weed because it grew in a cesspool area.
And what did you start saying?
Go ahead.
I was just going to ask, did you have any physical exercise or did you exercise in your cells?
Most of us exercised every day in our cells, you know, just run in place.
doing a little calisthenics and that sort of thing.
You mentioned the sewer soup.
With the conditions and climate, illnesses must have been common.
Did you have any means of trying to prevent illnesses?
Did they allow any medication or anything like that?
Well, from time to time, and that went up and down with the moods and the so-called treatment at the time.
They would claim to have medical people attend to people who asked for it and so on.
But it was not anything that I would ever ask for.
And yeah, we had sicknesses from time to time.
We had a gross epidemic one time of pinkeye.
awfulest mess you've ever seen, and virtually 99% of everybody in the cells got it.
Just went through like wildfire.
And it lasted a week or so, but everybody's eyes were just unbelievable.
Looked like the whites were like real red egg whites that were kind of spilling out of your eyelids, you know, just all swollen.
Felt like
Your eyes were full of gravel.
And there was a lot of diarrhea, of course, and dysentery and stuff like that.
But nothing really was ever done about it.
Besides physical exercises, did you have mental exercises?
I talked to some of the POWs, and they mentally constructed things or mentally read books.
What did you try to do?
Oh yeah, it was fantastic some of the things that people did up there.
I know Nolan Daughtry reconstructed all the trigonometry love rhythms.
A couple of times he did that, went through that exercise.
On paper, he got it down because we would, you know, we'd get
toilet paper, real rough old brown paper, just sheets of it.
And we had, we used all kinds of different things to write with.
We found a little piece of stick and sharpened it on the concrete and mixed cigarette ashes with, later on we had Kool-Aid from the packages sometimes and some sugar.
And that sort of thing, and make something, make an ink that would write nicely.
But so anyhow, a lot of that kind of thing.
People designed houses.
And then later on, when we got into bigger groups, we had a lot of classes.
But just as an example, I spent about three months, a little over three months in solitary confinement in the spring of 1980.
1971, I think.
Yeah, it was after the Sante raid, and we all moved back to Hanoi.
They piled us all in the Hilton again.
And it was in that spring.
There was another guy, a friend who was also in solitary in the Heartbreak Hotel cell block, which is where we were.
And I never smoked.
But we always got a little ration of three cigarettes a day.
Usually, I think.
And I always took mine and gave them to the smokers, you know.
But anyhow, when I was in solitary, I'd take my cigarette ration and wrap it in a little piece of paper and deposit it in an area.
And they had what we called the shower.
There was a little
a faucet in there that dripped a little bit.
And we were allowed in there, though, every day for a few minutes, or most every day.
And I had a way of communicating with this fellow.
And he was an expert in several subjects.
But French was his big thing.
He kind of taught himself French by swiping
French publications when he went to quiz and so on with the D, and he'd have a similar one in English, so he'd just look at the different transcript of the French, and he'd talk himself French.
So he was leaving me French lessons every day, and I left him my cigarettes.
The French lessons...
were written out on toilet paper.
He found a little chunk of lime.
They use a lot of lime to whitewash walls with and that sort of thing.
And you could use that to write with, too.
So I studied French for those three months.
I'd like to ask you some questions about how different events affected prisoners' treatments.
What about when Nixon started bombing Cambodia?
Was there a change in the treatment, or did you even know that was going on?
Oh, yeah.
We got their version of what was going on in the war all the time.
They'd turn on the loudspeaker at night in the cells, and it was very difficult to understand.
and most people didn't even bother and didn't even try to listen.
I usually listen some just to try to read between the lines and see what I could pick up.
But yes, the treatment was up and down a lot and it did seem to vary with how the war was going and that sort of thing throughout the years.
But
It was hard to predict what their reaction was going to be.
Their propaganda was everything was going in their favor all the time.
During the Paris peace talks, did y'all find out about those going on?
Oh, yeah.
We heard about them.
What about when North Vietnamese sympathizers like Jane Fonda came over to y'all?
I'm sure they used that as heavy propaganda.
Did they let y'all know that she was coming over?
Well, they used her and all of those kinds of people to the nth degree.
And what they tried to do was set up a situation to portray what they wanted them to see to take back to the world.
Well, most of us.
Never saw any of those people.
All we heard was what we heard on the box.
We'd hear her making her anti-U.S. statements and that sort of thing.
But she would visit with, they had a few POWs isolated somewhere away from us that were cooperative with them.
in exchange, I guess, for good treatment or whatever.
And so those are the people that they got to see.
Did you go on the march through Hanoi when everybody's going back to the Hilton?
No, that occurred before I was shot down.
Okay.
the famous march.

Now that was just a deal where they came and got all the prisoners one night and marched them through the streets to let the people, to incite the people into hating the American air pirates, that sort of thing.
That was the purpose of that.
It was pretty infamous because it caused a lot of uproar throughout the world when they saw films of that, of the bad treatment of prisoners by the Vietnamese.
The Tet Offensive happened right after your capture, a month after your capture.
Did you hear anything about that either before or after?
Did you hear any rumors before or after your capture?
Well, not before, I don't think.
But the Tet Offensive was just a part of all the propaganda-type war news that they routinely put out.
At the time, I knew you could tell that there indeed was some heavy fighting and all that in the South.
But it didn't sound extraordinary to me.
It just sounded like routine war news.
So I didn't pay a heck of a lot of attention to it.
After you were finally released and came back to the United States, how did you handle the transition from being captive to free again?
Was it difficult to realize that you were actually free at first or just when they told you the news?
No.
You know, all the years I was up there, I always associated with or, you know, affiliated
with the guys who we called the optimists.
We had two different types of people.
Obviously, most of us, I think, were optimists and felt like we kept kidding ourselves, at least, that we're going to get out sooner rather than later.
And if Christmas was coming up, well, we'd say, well, we're going to be home by Christmas, no problem.
And that went on for about six Christmases, you know.
But then if Christmas didn't make it, well, it was New Year's or Tet or Easter or the Fourth of July or whatever.
But we always had a target date, you know, and we felt like one of these days one of them was going to hit and we weren't going to get the release.
So we all had assured ourselves that we were going to be released.
The other guys...
We called the VODs, the Voices of Doom, and said, you know, we're never going to get out of here.
We're going to be here for the rest of our lives and so on.
But anyhow, so, yeah, I expected to get released.
And, of course, I was very elated to get released.
And I didn't have any trouble adjusting to being free again.
That's the easiest thing I ever tried to do in my life.

The reason why I asked that, I had read some, not from the Vietnam War, but from the World War II prisoners of war that had trouble realizing that they could actually do things over again without worrying about repercussions.
What was the impact of being a POW on your career and your life?
Well, other than just being on hold for about five and a half years.
But, you know, we were, it wasn't totally lost because we were at a military organization as POWs and we were operating in a
in a very tough, realistically tough environment.
So there was a lot to be learned from that.
And I think many of us, at least, I believe, benefited a lot from those years of operating in an organization under those conditions.
So we learned and matured through that, I think.
So all you know.
I feel like that had I not been shot down, that I would have had more opportunities maybe in my career.
But gosh, I couldn't have possibly had things happen any better for me career-wise after I was shot down.
During the rest of my active duty career, my assignments were the greatest.
I couldn't have asked for anything better.
than I had.
So, you know, it turned out real well, for me at least.
I'd like to get your opinions on a couple of subjects.
Do you think we should use our troops in a military conflict without a firm commitment from our government to win?
Like a similar, you know, to Vietnam?
Obviously, you know, that
The answer to that question is pretty obvious.
We should not be involved in something that we're not going to be committed to win if we're going to expose our troops to the hazards that they were exposed to there.
But the military is an instrument of government.
And I feel like that our government ought to have the freedom to use the military arm for what it's for.
And I think it has application in places like Lebanon and in Central America.
Those kinds of situations are very, very difficult to handle politically.
And if the military can help out with that,
And that's our job, and we ought to do it.
I don't think we ought to get involved in a big, full-scale war in Lebanon like we did in Vietnam, certainly.
But I think what we're doing over there is not unreasonable, and it's something that we need to do and should do to help at least to give...
the Lebanese government the opportunity to get stabilized.
Okay.
In Reiser's book again, he believed that the longer anybody was in camp, the more nationalistic and more religious that person became.
Do you agree with that statement?
I think what he's probably saying there is that
I think as a general rule it did apply to most of us up there, that more patriotic, is that what you mean?
Yes, more patriotic.
See, we depended totally on our country to get us out of there.
So we had to believe in our country if we ever expected to get out of there, right?
And I think that was part of that.
Now there were a few who turned the other way.
So I guess that's the point he was making there.
And then, of course, the other thing that many of us would also depend on, since we are pretty helpless to do anything very positive ourselves, we turn to God to help us.
And so I think religion, if you ever had any,
would be more pronounced in a situation like that because you need every bit of help you can get.
Let me change the tape over.
